title: Chord Construction
content: The definition of a chord is two or more notes played at the same time. These can be any notes, but usually they are within the same scale as each other.
Chords come in many shapes and sizes, but the most common chord you’ll come across is the primary triad.

title: Note
content: Now, an important difference to remember when using chords is the first note isn’t called the tonic, we call it the root. This is a small difference but it’s helpful to differentiate between, for example, the scale of C major and a chord of C major.

title: The primary triad
content: The primary triad is made up of 3 notes (tri means 3). Now, when we say notes, we don’t mean specific notes but instead degrees on a scale - namely, the tonic, the mediant, and the dominant, or degrees 1, 3 and 5.

title: The primary triad
content: To test this out, let’s construct the primary triad of C major. We know the root (not the tonic!) is C, as it’s the name of the scale. The third note in C major (the mediant) is E, and the dominant is G. Therefore, the primary triad of C major is CEG. If you don’t know where we got these notes, check back through the scale degrees topic (don’t worry, it can take a while to memorise all the degrees!).
